column4: Qn.2: How many of the original developers of the mainline maintained the variant in its first 6 months?
column5: Qn.3: Do the variant and mainline have common active maintainers?
column6: Qn.4: What was the motivation of creating the variant of the mainline project?   [TECHNICAL. The variant was introduced to target specific needs or user segments that are not accommodated by the mainline project]
column7: Qn.4: What was the motivation of creating the variant of the mainline project?   [GOVERNANCE DISPUTES. The variant was created because some of the contributors felt that their feedback was not heard or maintainers were accepting patches too slowly in the mainline project.]
column8: Qn.4: What was the motivation of creating the variant of the mainline project?   [LEGAL. The mainline or variant wanted to change its license or change its laws (e.g., regarding encryption) requiring technical changes.]
column9: Qn.4: What was the motivation of creating the variant of the mainline project?   [PERSONAL. There were interpersonal disputes and irreconcilable differences of a non-technical nature that led to a rift between various parties.]

column11:
The original goal of the mainline is completely different from the fork variant.  While the projects are related in the sense that they share a similar code base, they are very different pieces of software.  The mainline for example, ensures backward comparability with the retail release of the original game (Jedi Academy), while our fork introduces hundreds of new features/changes but is not backwards compatible or ever intended to be.

Specifically the mainline branch states in readme that' it's purpose is to: "is an effort....to maintain and improve the game engines on which the....games run on, while maintaining full backwards compatibility with the existing games. This project does not attempt to rebalance or otherwise modify core gameplay."  Meanwhile our variant rebalances and completely modifies core gameplay without maintaining backwards compatibility.

We still maintain a connection to the mainline because many of the fixes/changes introduced there may occasionally be applicable (for example engine fixes), but we rarely ever push changes made on our fork upstream since they would rarely ever be applicable to the mainline project.
column13: We will discuss things if we have common issues that need to be solved (eg a security issue that both projects have to fix), but otherwise discussion is unneeded.

We submitted some bugfixes to the original/mainline repo, but didn't hear back from the maintainer for a while and needed to progress to meet our own goals so we forked.

I followed up over email with the maintainer and he merged the patches about a month later, at which point we closed down and archived our fork and returned to using the mainline.

column11: The mainline project had made a radical shift from providing one set of features (pip-review + pip-dump) to a different, disjoint set of features (pip-compile + pip-sync). The maintainer had thought about it very well, but some users (including myself) had built their workflows around one of the old features. For this reason, I lifted that particular feature (pip-review) into a separate project that was also published under a different name to the package index. For these historical reasons, the mainline and the variant are not really alternatives to each other; rather, they are complementary.

column4: 1, maintainer
column5: Yes, they have common maintainers
column11: The variant in this case is an exact copy of the original. The reason it was created is because 5 years ago the permissions model for GitHub and Travis is not what it is today. I was using my X github account for work, and I had access to a few private repos containing customer code. I wanted to use Travis for CI/CD but if I granted Travis access to my primary github account, it would have read access to all the github repos that the X github account had access to, which would expose private customer code to Travis unnecessarily. So, I simply created a second github account and forked the repo so that I could grant Travis access without compromising the privacy of the customer code on my main account. Since then, the permissions model has evolved so I don't believe an approach like this is necessary any more. In fact, I have a pending task to switch to github actions for CI/CD on the main repo, and to delete the fork, but I have yet to do that.
column13: They are effectively the same repository
column20: All changes in the mainline repo are synced to the variant, and vice versa.

column11: The variant was always intended to be temporary. I needed to make changes to the internal workings of the library. I needed to be able to distribute those changes to colleagues. Mainline was not ready to accept those changes in part because the maintainers were not responsive. Since that time all of the issues have been dealt with and my variant is no longer needed, though the infrastructure for creating a new release of the variant remains in place in the event that it might be needed in the future. That said, the burden of maintaining a separate variant is quite high, so now that mainline has new, responsive maintainers, it is much more effective to get changes incorporated upstream.

column11:
We use this as a dependency in another project: an open source commercial project who is maintained by our company.

The main reason for forking (OTHER) is to make sure that no matter what happen to the mainline repository, we can maintain source access to this library, which is an essential dependency of our project. E.g. if the mainline repository was to be deleted / forced pushed to rewrite the history completely, we could not compile our project anymore as the dependency could not be compiled. By forking, we make sure we have access to the dependency source code.

The secondary reason for forking (TECHNICAL) was to keep the source code compatible with the language/compiler version that we use (Swift / Xcode). Sometimes new versions of Swift break source compatibility, if we update (or not update when there is a new one) the compiler but the maintainer of the mainline is supporting a different one, then we could not compile our dependency anymore.
column13: No, there has never been any discussion since the creation of the variant
column20: We occasionally pull the changes from mainline to apply security / bug fixes. We do not cherry pick the changes, we just pull everything.
column27: We use this as a dependency in another project. We make little change in the forked version other than to maintain compatibility to the language version that we use for our main project, which is often diverging from the language version of the mainline, so there is little reason for us to push this to mainline.

column11: Background: the repos in question are for a game. The mainline and variant have different playerbases (and thus communities) with different gameplay tastes. It was decided very early on that following in lock-step with mainline would make integrating custom gameplay features difficult. It's also a very large burder on the variant's development community to try and stay up to date the mainline, specially if the mainline has a more active development cycle (which it very much did in the beginning). So a hard decoupling made it easier for us to live our own life. Also, purely a technical reason: remaining forked on github introduces limitations on certain things (like no repo search).
column13: Technical solutions get swapped in both directions as osmosis. Creative decisions (since we're both games) are kept very separate, though.
column27: The community level leadership of mainline and variant still communicate. Major issues, such as critical security issues, are usually communicated very fast on that level. However, it's often left up to either development community to pull the fixes from the originating repo, instead of the original fixers PR-ing back to mainline.

column11: Personally I don't consider this to be a variant of the original project. This fork exists only for  the localization purposes. The author of this original project used this method to let the community around the world to contribute to the translation in their own language. When the translation was done, the owner of the forked repo would email a link to the final project to the author of the original repo, and he would update the landing page for this project with a link to the localized build of the project.
column13: The project was almost finished at the time, so I don't consider there are new features added other than the new translations.
